    • Method Detail

      • getAbsoluteDaysDifference

        public static int getAbsoluteDaysDifference(java.util.Date oldDate,
                            java.util.Date recentDate)
        Gives the difference in days between the two days. This does not round up, so, if you were to give it January 1st, 2012 12:00:00.000 and January 2nd, 2012 11:59:59.999 it would return 0 because the milliseconds difference between those is not full day. If you would rather have this functionality, use the getDaysDifference method.
        Parameters:
        oldDate -
        recentDate -
        Returns:

      • getDaysDifference

        public static int getDaysDifference(java.util.Date oldDate,
                    java.util.Date recentDate)
        Gets the days difference. This is different than getAbsoluteDaysDifference because this will not take anything smaller than the day into account (so, for example, if you give it December 31st, 1999 at 23:59:59.999 and January 1st, 2000 at 00:00:00.000 it will return 1, whereas getAbsoluteDaysDifference on those days would return 0 because the actual difference between those two times is 1 millisecond
        Parameters:
        oldDate -
        recentDate -
        Returns:

      • getDaysSinceZero

        public static int getDaysSinceZero(int era,
                   int yearOfEra,
                   int dayOfYear)
        Gets the days since 0 by creating a calendar instance, setting the era and then iterating from 0 to the given year getting the maximum day of the year for each of those years and adding that number until finally it reaches the year given and then adds the dayOfYear given. Returns negative if the era != 1; (which is AD)
        Parameters:
        era -
        yearOfEra -
        dayOfYear -
        Returns:

      • nanosecondsToString

        public static java.lang.String nanosecondsToString(long nanoseconds)
        Converts a long time in nanoseconds to a formatted timestamp. Useful for timing operations. Simply use long begin = System.nanoTime(); ...some operation... long end = System.nanoTime(); nanoToString(end - begin);
        Parameters:
        nanoseconds -
        Returns:

      • getDateFormatter

        public static java.text.SimpleDateFormat getDateFormatter()
        Returns:
        the dateFormatter. Default is ("MMM d, yyyy").

      • setDateFormatter

        public static void setDateFormatter(java.text.SimpleDateFormat aDateFormatter)
        Parameters:
        aDateFormatter - the dateFormatter to set. Default is ("MMM d, yyyy").
